issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
In the beginning we had the property walrus.storagemaxcachesizeinmb set too low. when the limit exceeded, Walrus failed to cache the large windows image. 

Then after increasing the property value, caching still fails. Further debugging and code review reveals that imageCachers map which maps from manifest path to the ImageCacher thread continue to hold the entry after the failures. The next attempt to cache all fails because WalrusManager think caching is in progress (WalrusImageMananager.java: 1290).

To fix the issue, I had to restart the CLC to get rid of ImageCacher in the map.

comments.body: This is likely the same issue. Will investigate to determine if they are the same root cause.
I can see this in 3.3.0 cloud as well. Is the fix coming in 3.3.1? I see the fixed version points at 3.3.1.
Any more details here?  Exactly how is this fixed in 3.3.1? :S
It is not yet fixed in 3.3.1, but will be. Should be in the code over the weekend.

Thanks [~zhill].  Also, this issue should have been resolvable by de-registering the image and re-registering it.  This would cause the image cache process to start over when trying to run an instance.
I'm linking a pretty useful SUP ticket which has some reproduction info in it.

Looking at this more it appears the core issue is that the actual caching tasks take a really long time to completely fail. The retries keep waiting for 30 minutes and the NC sends 3 retries, so while these are basically in parallel, it can still take 30 minutes to fully fail the cache attempt. At that point I'm seeing the imageCacher marker flushed correctly. There was a bug in how the exponential backoff was implemented such that any backoff would affect *all* backoffs and never reset the backoff timer so the wait time just kept increasing for any failed cache attempt.

I have fixed that bug and changed the timeouts to do 10s checks and 180 of them rather than 10 minute checks and only doing 3. That gives the same total timeout but should make the checks more frequent such that it will fail faster.

I've also added a ton of logging to the process. You can follow a specific getDecryptedImage request using the CorrelationID and all cache tasks are now marked with their threadId in the log so you can track each task and request individually from start to finish.

Example:
{code}

See internal repo commit: 2eba1bece45adf81e6cbd2176cb85672eb7ef4d3 public repo commit: 72d73e81eed09c6bc57c294ccf5957fcc06544a6

New behavior: 
Fast failure for images too large to fix in cache. No images are flushed, the request is failed if the image size is larger than the cache size.

New configurable property (cloud.images.maximagesizegb) that is checked at image registration time to send error message to user if attempting to register an image that is larger than the max set by the admin, that max may be the same as the cache size or not, the two are decoupled but not independent.

Passed the standard euca-sequence-3.3-dns suite. Also did manual testing with images that exceed the max size as well as cache flushing and manual churn. Also tested decreasing the cache size and verified that images are flushed to reach the new configured size.

Needed additional testing: 
The image churn test Matt has been working on.
Documentation task for the new configurable property.

verified the new property, and running image churn now. So far so good. Pending that outcome will resolve this issue. 
Thanks,
-M
{code}
euca-register tmplrwn0uyufn/precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-ext3.img.manifest.xml -n test3
euca-register: error (RegisterImageType): Cannot register image of size 1468006400 bytes because it exceeds the configured maximum instance-store image size of 1 GB. Please contact your administrator 

[root@b-02 ~]# euca-modify-property -p cloud.images.maximagesizegb=2
PROPERTY	cloud.images.maximagesizegb	2 was 1

[root@b-02 ~]# euca-register tmplrwn0uyufn/precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-ext3.img.manifest.xml -n test3
IMAGE	emi-AD6939E8

{code}

GIT_HASH fc873b8e55979ffb0e1e3d2a63971623af01e798
Verified that the walrus.storagemaxcachesizeinmb property by attempting to run an image larger than the cache. Then increasing the property and retrying w/o restarting any services. 
The new log/err messages are useful here:
{code}

2013-10-17 22:20:32 DEBUG 000211173 WalrusImageManager       | Checking image size of 17179869184 bytes against current cache max size of 2147483648 bytes
2013-10-17 22:20:32 ERROR 000211173 WalrusImageManager       | [CorrelationId: 6a0fdf90-6d77-49c0-a4bb-9b230fe5c6fd | Account: 690960315323] Aborting image part assembly because image is too large to fit in cache
...
...
013-10-17 22:32:40 DEBUG 000211575 WalrusImageManager       | Checking image size of 17179869184 bytes against current cache max size of 18253611008 bytes
2013-10-17 22:32:40  INFO 000211575 WalrusImageManager       | [CorrelationId: 9370aca8-6a93-4259-82a5-93b2960096fc | Account: 690960315323] Assembling parts for image windows8/windows2008_8_21_12.img.manifest.xml into file: //var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/windows8/4a683914-0bd2-4018-88b0-780af4acff06.crypt.gz

{code}
Verified images cached and instances run from these went to running, and functioned properly. 

Also ran image churn (running instances from multiple images in a loop) on this system with a low cache size. Ran into another issue (euca-7942) which resulted in some failures, but so it looks like the cache behaved fine. Will re-open if I find otherwise. 
Thanks!
-M
